And given a start and a goal uh we try
to connect it using an indictive route.
So an indicative route indicates how a
character globally wants to walk or move
uh through an environment uh connecting
the start with the goal. Then uh
iteratively typically 10 times per
second we pick a point on this route and
we try to follow it. Well this gives us
a velocity so a certain direction and
speed in which the character is moving
into. But it's not only for one
character it's for potentially thousands
or hundreds of thousands of characters.
So uh what we do is each character looks
in its neighborhood typically to its uh
nearest seven or 10 entities and uh is
going to update this velocity based on
things that happen around this
character. So uh collision avoidance is

flow or uh walking in a certain

high density uh uh situations.
uh and finally we have a velocity which

uh I'll walk through uh these layers one
by one. First a representation of the
environment.
So um you see that uh most game engines
uh are using the reccast detour library
which is open source created by makeona.
So this has really become the industry
standard. uh you can download it, you
can play with it and it works in a few
steps. So the first step is you're given
a 3D environment. Uh in the second
picture uh the environment is being
voxalized on the GPU and all the voxels
that are sitting on top of an obstacle
are kept in the next phase. You see that
in the third picture a uh flood filling
algorithm is applied. So you you apply a
seed to a a voxil that hasn't been
classified yet and you basically use a
seed growing algorithm to find uh pixels
or voxels uh that are roughly on the
same height. Uh then an algorithm is
used to trace the boundaries of the
polygon that's formed by these voxels.
Well, this can yield non-convex so
complex polygons. So these are being
decomposed into a set of convex ones so
that you can make easy computations with
it. Uh in the next phase uh a navigation
graph is extracted. So basically you put
a vertex on each polygon and you place
an edge that connects a vertex to
another one to a neighbor polygon uh if
the polygons are adjacent to each other.
And in this way you create a navigation
mesh. And navigation mesh is a
combination of a surface representation
here in blue uh plus a graph. And a
graph is typically used for planning
global path using an AAR algorithm that
can compute a shortest path in a graph.
Okay. So uh this is the basis that's
often used and also used by an real
engine. But uh this uh method has many
issues especially if you want to deal
with huge environments. So we have been
working on digital twins of thousands of
squared kilometers and you cannot use
recast for these purposes. Um also it
has lots of issues with narrow passages
uh to get characters through because
it's a voxalized environment. Um so it
is discretized.
Uh also um it has issues with difficult
geometry like if you have a stair and it
has different step heights. So this
method has also many uh parameters to
deal with these issues. So sometimes it
takes a lot of time to calibrate all
these parameters to get the right
output. Uh so we have been working on uh
other techniques so uh exact techniques
um to uh compute in an exact way a
representation
uh that can be used as a navigation
mesh. But such an exact technique where
we are using exact number types are very
expensive. So even in this very simple
house case uh we computed a multilate
environment but it took like 8 seconds
to compute and it consumed 1 GBTE of
memory. So suppose you have a huge game
world it's not going to work. It's not
going to scale. Uh so we had to develop
other techniques uh that were fast but
still exact or precise I have to say.
Um so uh in my opinion an ideal
navigation mesh has to satisfy these uh
criteria. It has perfect coverage
meaning that uh if there is a place
where a character can stand then this
location should also be represented in a
data structure that goes with the u
navigation mesh. In addition, it has
perfect connectivity. So if there is a
path in the game world that connects or
start with a goal, then this path also
should be able to be retrieved via the
data structure. Uh it should be computed
efficiently, implemented robustly and
should require little storage. So that
also can be used on machines with
constrainted memories. Um and it also
allows for fast path planning queries.
So hundreds of thousands in real time.
Okay. So this has led to uh this data
structure. So as input we are given in
in this case it's a planer environment.
So an environment that just sits in 2D.
Uh it is created by a set of vertices
that describe obstacles. in this case a
bounding box uh plus a footprint of
polygons. Now based on this information
uh there are libraries also open
libraries like a boost library that can
compute a voroi diagram or a medial axis
of the environment and this is basically
a graph uh that has edges and these
edges are furthest away from obstacles
and this allows you to to do all kinds
of nice mathematical operations. It
gives you a uh a graph that represents
all motions that can be made and we
annotate this graph with uh information.
So we um subdivide the environment into
a set of non-over overlapping cells so
that each uh reachable point actually is
represented by the data structure. Um so
in mathematical terms or computer
science terms when the environment is
defined in n vertices it it can be
stored in order n memory. So it's just
linear uh and it can be constructed in
nlog end time which is really fast.
Um and this uh structure uh is really
nice because you only have to compute
one navigation mesh uh that can be
queried by characters with a various
radius. So you only have to have one
mesh. uh you can compute uh uh like the
points on this middle axis which allows
you to do uh distance operations uh uh
very cheaply and distance operations is
like a basic operation you need in crowd
simulations a lot to determine what's
the distance to obstacles what's the
distance to other things and you get it
for free basically uh this structure
also allows you to compute a corridor uh
that can be like a set of corridors real
corridors in a building like this one
But it also can be like a set of
streets. So it defines a blob of free
space through which characters can move.
And this structure allows you to compute
a set of path that can be the shortest
path for a point or a shortest path for
a disk. So basically uh characters with
an arbitrary radius. It also uh gives
you all kinds of operations uh that are
very fast to compute um like computing

for disks um etc. And this structure uh
can also be extended to multi-late
environments. So like a planer
environment can have a triangulated
irregular network. So basically a height
mesh and we can concatenate these height

environment. And all these properties I
just said so like computing visibility
computing shortest path for disks can
also be done in the same time uh in
these multilate environments. Um and
that's good. You can also update such a
navigation mesh in real time uh even
when there are 100 thousand characters
using the mesh and in this way
characters don't get stuck which is
good.

XYZ uh velocity animation state uh plus

Um but then it was really difficult to

So um and um so we switched from using a

So we made cache aware algorithms. Uh we

as possible. Sometimes you have to

deliberately.
